summary.p: [1] Bullinger thanks for Myconius’ letter [No. 2855]. He has already conveyed his news [with No. 2850] through Christoph Froschauer.
[2] Francisco de Enzinas should be informed that Bullinger has received everything well from him.

[3] It is certain that the Bohemians do not want to go to war [against Elector Johann Friedrich of Saxony]. Bullinger has read the manifesto of their uprising directed [against Ferdinand I.]. Therefore, the Elector does not need to fear them.

[4] Myconius should immediately deliver the enclosed letter to Sebastian Münster, so that he can entrust the money [intended for Erasmus Oswald Schreckenfuchs] to the bearer [Andreas Müller] of the present letter.
[5] Greetings to Johannes Gast and thanks for his letter [No. 2848].
[6] Also, greetings to the colleagues and friends. In haste.

div.p: Greetings. I have received your letters, most esteemed Myconius, and I thank you for your faithfulness and effort. I have written what I had to say through Froschauer.
Tell Dr. Dryander that I have received everything and express my gratitude.

It is certain that the Bohemians have conspired not to bear arms outside their own territory. I have seen and read the written conspiracy. Therefore, the Elector has no reason to fear them in this regard.
You will ensure that this letter is immediately delivered to Dr. Münster, so that he can hand over the money to me through this specific messenger.
Convey my friendly greetings to Gast and thank him for his most diligent letters.
Farewell. Greet the brothers and friends. March 23, 1547. In great haste. Your Bullinger.
To the most distinguished man, Dr. Oswald Myconius, most esteemed lord and brother. Basel.
